text: MARTINA NAVRATILOVA:

has the edge against
Roger Federer,

but that was on slower
surfaces, particularly clay.
This is a hard court.
And it's playing fast.

And that is what
Roger Federer loves.

So I would say it's a
50%, 50% proposition
because of the court.

If it was slower like
it was last year,
I'd say Rafa has the edge.

But now the court's faster,
the balls are faster,

and Rafa just had a
grueling, grueling match
against Dimitrov.

MICHAEL CHANG: I mean,
it's a tough call.

I mean, I think the extra day
for Roger to have off, I think,
is important for him.

Both obviously coming off
of really tough five set
matches, but Rafa's fit.

He looked really
strong yesterday,

even in the latter stages of
playing a five hour match.
It's going to be a great match.

LINDSAY DAVENPORT: It's so hard
to pick either one of them.

Obviously, you go to the head
to head and that favors Rafa.

But the court speed and
the extra day's rest
really favors Roger.

Overall, I think just tennis
wins, fans win, sports wins.

And at this point, being
a huge fan of both,

I'm going to be
happy either way.

ROD LAVER: I don't think I can
pick a winner, because I think
they are so evenly matched.

And they both-- depending
on how they play,

because I know that someone
with a big forehand like Nadal,

he's going to push it into
Roger's backhand side.

So you just have to
sort of enjoy the match,
I think, is what I'll do.
